If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X ‚Üí E} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {k : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f ‚Üí IsCompact k ‚Üí MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f k
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

For any positive real number `T`, any `t` in real numbers, and any integrable function `f` from the additive circle of `T` to a normed additive commutative group over real numbers, the integral of `f` over the interval `(t, t + T]` is equal to the integral of `f` over the entire additive circle of `T`.

type:
‚àÄ (T : ‚Ñù) [hT : Fact (0 < T)] {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] (t : ‚Ñù)
  (f : AddCircle T ‚Üí E), ‚à´ (a : ‚Ñù) in Set.Ioc t (t + T), f ‚Üëa = ‚à´ (b : AddCircle T), f b
name: AddCircle.integral_preimage
docString: For any positive real number `T`, any `t` in real numbers, and any integrable function `f` from the additive circle of `T` to a normed additive commutative group over real numbers, the integral of `f` over the interval `(t, t + T]` is equal to the integral of `f` over the entire additive circle of `T`.

This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `‚ÑÇ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] (f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E) (c : ‚ÑÇ),
  (‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, 0), f z) = 0
name: circleIntegral.integral_radius_zero
docString: This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `‚ÑÇ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ‚ÑÇ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M ‚Üí F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ‚ÑÇ F) f ‚Üí ‚àÄ (a b : M), f a = f b
name: MDifferentiable.apply_eq_of_compactSpace
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

For any real number T > 0 and any function f from the additive circle of T to a normed additive commutative group with a real normed space, the integral of f over (t, t + T] equals the integral of its restriction to the additive circle of T.

type:
‚àÄ (T : ‚Ñù) [hT : Fact (0 < T)] {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] (t : ‚Ñù)
  (f : AddCircle T ‚Üí E), ‚à´ (a : ‚Ñù) in t..t + T, f ‚Üëa = ‚à´ (b : AddCircle T), f b
name: AddCircle.intervalIntegral_preimage
docString: For any real number T > 0 and any function f from the additive circle of T to a normed additive commutative group with a real normed space, the integral of f over (t, t + T] equals the integral of its restriction to the additive circle of T.

This is the statement of H√∂lder's inequality for integrable functions. It states that, given a measurable space and a measure on this space, and a normed field acting on a normed additively commutative group, if we have an integrable function from the measurable space to the normed group, then for any function from the measurable space to the normed field that is strongly measurable almost everywhere, and whose essential supremum of its norm is finite, the function obtained by pointwise multiplication of these two functions is also integrable. In simpler terms, the scalar multiplication of an integrable vector-valued function by a scalar function with finite essential supremum is integrable.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} {m : MeasurableSpace Œ±} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup Œ≤]
  {ùïú : Type u_5} [inst_1 : NormedField ùïú] [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú Œ≤] {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f Œº ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {g : Œ± ‚Üí ùïú},
      MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g Œº ‚Üí
        essSup (fun x => ‚Üë‚Äñg x‚Äñ‚Çä) Œº ‚â† ‚ä§ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.Integrable (fun x => g x ‚Ä¢ f x) Œº
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.essSup_smul
docString: This is the statement of H√∂lder's inequality for integrable functions. It states that, given a measurable space and a measure on this space, and a normed field acting on a normed additively commutative group, if we have an integrable function from the measurable space to the normed group, then for any function from the measurable space to the normed field that is strongly measurable almost everywhere, and whose essential supremum of its norm is finite, the function obtained by pointwise multiplication of these two functions is also integrable. In simpler terms, the scalar multiplication of an integrable vector-valued function by a scalar function with finite essential supremum is integrable.

A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

docString: H√∂lder's inequality in case of finite non-zero integrals
